pullRequest.body:
* Generalise definition of a semireal ring, as discussed at https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Formally.20real.20fields
* Add facts about multiplicative structure of sums of squares -- preserved under multiplication, form a semiring, set of sums of squares is the semiring generated by the squares.
* Rename several definitions in Algebra/Ring/SumsOfSquares for consistency.
* Add missing theorems about substructures by analogy with existing ones, to facilitate the above.

This is work towards formalising some real algebra (see https://github.com/artie2000/real_closed_field).

- [ ] depends on: #20269
- [x] depends on: #20271
- [ ] depends on: #20272

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).

> You are missing `IsSumSq.sum` and `IsSumSq.prod`

Added
I'm back! Updated and cleaned up everything.

> The main changes in this PR appear in the module `Mathlib.Algebra.Ring.SumsOfSquares`.
> 
> A new induction principle for sums of squares has been added (though it has not found a use yet) and several results have been added to treat inductively-defined sums of squares using a sum operator instead. Several results that were previously proved using induction have now been refactored to use this approach.
> 
> The added results are all useful, so my opinion is that we should merge these changes. My only concern lies with the `@[deprecated (since := "0204-08-09")]` attributes, which I wish we could get rid of on the occasion of the current refactoring.

The new material is useful generally, but specifically is required to prove that a field is semireal if and only if it can be ordered -- PR on the way ;)

And yeah not too sure about the alternative induction principle -- the motivation for it is that `IsSquare x` is easier to work with than `x * x` in practice, but I haven't actually found an application where it matters.

> For reviewing, it would help if you split that PR in two or three

Is there some way to link them together, so that eg the changes to `Group.Even` file structure make sense?

> Is there some way to link them together, so that eg the changes to `Group.Even` file structure make sense?

Do you mean the `- [ ] depends on:` syntax in the PR description?

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#20269~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#20271~~
* leanprover-community/mathlib4#20272
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
You are missing `IsSumSq.sum` and `IsSumSq.prod`

The main changes in this PR appear in the module `Mathlib.Algebra.Ring.SumsOfSquares`. 

A new induction principle for sums of squares has been added (though it has not found a use yet) and several results have been added to treat inductively-defined sums of squares using a sum operator instead. Several results that were previously proved using induction have now been refactored to use this approach. 

The added results are all useful, so my opinion is that we should merge these changes. My only concern lies with the `@[deprecated (since := "0204-08-09")]` attributes, which I wish we could get rid of on the occasion of the current refactoring.
For reviewing, it would help if you split that PR in two or three

```suggestion
  not_IsSumSq_neg_one (a : R) (ssa : IsSumSq a) : ¬ (a + 1 = 0)
```
Would it also make sense to correct and get rid of the deprecated declarations? These were due to an error in the convention used (`isSumSq` is preferable over `IsSumSq` *etc*).
I didn't want to remove them in case it broke downstream projects, but since I rewrote some declarations anyway I guess it makes sense to remove them all. Should I proceed?
I would think so! But if you prefer to wait for @YaelDillies's opinion, that's also fine (there's no rush).
I was actually worried about some project *you* might have, so
Reverted as per https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16094#discussion_r1732221358

```suggestion
import Mathlib.Algebra.Order.Ring.Defs
import Mathlib.Algebra.Ring.SumsOfSquares
```

```suggestion
abbrev OrderedRing.toStrictOrderedRing (α : Type*) [OrderedRing α] [IsDomain α] :
```

```suggestion
-- See note [reducible non instances]
/-- Turn an ordered domain into a strict ordered ring. -/
```

Ops I forgot to revert these!
Can you suggest the same changes in the other PR?

```suggestion
  not_isSumSq_neg_one (a : R) (ssa : IsSumSq a) : 1 + a \ne 0
```
or maybe
```suggestion
  add_one_ne_zero_of_isSumSq (a : R) (ssa : IsSumSq a) : a + 1 \ne 0
```
Looks like you forgot to apply this?
I just checked and I'm pretty sure it's correct as of now.
Then maybe you forgot to push. I still see `¬ (1 + a = 0)` instead of `1 + a ≠ 0`
Oh sorry, I only saw the name change, my bad
Fixed
Are they really auxiliary definitions?
was following existing docs, changed

```suggestion
theorem IsSumSq.mul_self [AddZeroClass R] [Mul R] {a : R} : IsSumSq (a * a) := by
```
done

```suggestion
theorem IsSquare.isSumSq [AddZeroClass R] [Mul R] {x : R} (hx : IsSquare x) : IsSumSq x := by
```

I don't understand why you are doing induction here. Can't you first prove the obvious theorem that `IsSumSq a` iff `a` is a sum of squares (in terms of `Finset
sum`) then use `Finset.sum_mul_sum` to express the product of sums of squares as a sum of squares.

The predicate is defined inductively, so an induction proof is easy. I think the fact that a sum of squares can be written as.. as sum of squares is somehow implicit in the AddSubmonoid closure theorem?

As mentioned on Xena, the predicate is defined inductively because it would be annoying to state it using an indexed sum, but that doesn't forbid you from stating the indexed sum. And yes it is somehow implicit in the closure theorem, but you shouldn't expect your users from knowing that when they search for the fact that a sum of squares is a sum of squares!
Have found this theorem now (`Submonoid.exists_multiset_of_mem_closure`); still unsure about using `Finset.sum_mul_sum`. In particular, is there a lemma flattening two sums into one?

Basically I think `Finset.sum` is really fiddly and so the inducive definition is easier to work with. What I will do though is prove the 'obvious theorem' to characterise `IsSumSq` in terms of `Finset.sum`.

> Basically I think `Finset.sum` is really fiddly

That's an issue, not an issme. I can teach you how to use it. It really shouldn't be that hard

> As mentioned on Xena, the predicate is defined inductively because it would be annoying to state it using an indexed sum, but that doesn't forbid you from stating the indexed sum. And yes it is somehow implicit in the closure theorem, but you shouldn't expect your users from knowing that when they search for the fact that a sum of squares is a sum of squares!

Hi @YaelDillies ! May I ask what you mean when say 'as mentioned on Xena'?
Artie brought up my comment above on Kevin's Xena Discord server, and I replied there
Done

```suggestion
```
Can you try to keep this mostly alphabetical? Also please run `#min_imports`

Indexing types are usually denoted `ι`
```suggestion
    ∃ (ι : Type) (I : Finset ι) (f : ι → M), (∀ i ∈ I, f i ∈ s) ∧ ∏ i ∈ I, f i = x := by
```
Here too
I don't think there's huge value in listing all theorems here. The docs will already show them
Should I keep any? Or just delete the whole section? The previous version just listed everything, but I don't understand why.
I think just delete. The last two are the only ones worth mentioning in a `## Main declarations` section
OK, done
Why are you removing this deprecation?

Flo and I thought it would be fine, here
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16094#discussion_r1729199213
Should I reinstate deprecated names for those declarations which I haven't rewritten? I can understand why that would be sensible.
Yes, it looks like the policy is to keep the deprecations for 3-6 months and definitely at least one month so that they make it to at least one `stable` release

```suggestion
  | sq_add {a S : R} (hS : IsSumSq S) : IsSumSq (a * a + S)
```
will let you use dot notation on `hS`

hm
won't this cause a problem with requiring inference of `a`?

OK, it doesn't cause any problems within the current file, but I've been forced to use inference in a few places, and I'm worried that will cause problems down the line. Maybe I don't understand something about how this works in practice, though.
Please make `S` implicit, at least
I've made them both implicit; I think `a` should always be clear from the context, and you can always specify the type for the elaborator if needed

`finsum` already means something else
```suggestion
theorem isSumSq_iff_exists_finsetSum [AddCommMonoid R] [Mul R] (a : R) :
```

```suggestion
  | sq_add hS hS_ih => exact sq_add hS (.mul_self _) hS_ih
```
done

```suggestion
      ∃ (ι : Type) (I : Finset ι) (x : ι → R), (∀ i ∈ I, IsSquare (x i)) ∧ ∑ i ∈ I, x i = a :=
```

```suggestion
    ∃ (ι : Type u) (I : Finset ι) (x : ι → R), (∀ i ∈ I, IsSquare (x i)) ∧ ∑ i ∈ I, x i = a := by
```

Doesn't this work?
```suggestion
    ¬ IsSumSq (-1 : R) := by simpa using add_one_ne_zero_of_isSumSq
```
Typeclass inference on `Semireal ?_` fails

It usually is a bad idea to prove lemmas of the form "All elements in the closure of `s` are of form blah". Wherever you use those lemmas, there is a better proof using the closure induction principle, which is why those lemmas don't exist. Can you try rewriting your proofs without using this lemma?

This lemma already exists in the list and multiset versions, and I'm applying it in this PR to prove directly the specialisation where `s := SumSqIn R`.
Would you like me to effectively move this proof into the proof of `IsSumSq.exists_sum`?
Alternatively, we could remove all 6 explicit sum lemmas from `SumsOfSquares.lean`. In that case, the lemmas I really want, such as `IsSumSq.mul`, would have to be proved by induction. However, I'm confused as I thought you previously indicated that you prefer the explicit sum-rewriting proof of `IsSumSq.mul` to the inductive one.
I've just pushed a commit testing out the version without use of explicit sums (i.e., all done by induction). I'm happy with either; what do you (and others) think?
Sorry, I guess I'm not internally consistent on the matter 🙈 Could you bring it up on Zulip to see what people think?

RFC here:
https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/RFC.3A.20using.20vs.20avoiding.20explicit.20sum.20representations

@urkud has pointed out to me that the issue is not relevant as the result I want (`IsSumSq.mul`) has already been proved in more generality. The discussion is still worth having because the same decision will need to be made regarding material I intend to PR very soon.

I'm rewriting the PR according to @urkud 's suggestion; this involves filling in some missing general lemmas and also making a new file. Will re-request a review in the coming days. Thanks for all the comments and discussion!

```suggestion
    ∃ (ι : Type) (I : Finset ι) (x : ι → R), (∀ i ∈ I, IsSquare (x i)) ∧ ∑ i ∈ I, x i = a :=
```
oops cheers

**[imports (comment with "bot fix style" to have the bot commit all style suggestions)]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ```
I don't understand this suggestion. Could someone please explain it to me?
`Basic` comes after `Advanced` in alphabetical order

```suggestion
    M.subsemiringClosure.toNonUnitalSubsemiring = NonUnitalSubsemiring.closure M := by
```

```suggestion
theorem squareIn_toSubmonoid : (squareIn G).toSubmonoid = .squareIn G := rfl
```
Do we really need this? You can already do `rw [IsSquare`

My intention was to future-proof against definition changes and avoid possible defeq abuse in my code. This is can be used in more places eg `rw [IsSquare]` eg `(hx : IsSquare x) ... rcases hx with ...` becomes `rcases (isSquare_iff x).mp hx`.

I'm unaware of the existing conventions around definitions, though.
I doubt this definition will change ever again, so I don't think it's worth the trouble of avoiding defeq abuse

OK, will revert.
tbh I don't really understand when defeq is "bad" -- do you know of any resources documenting it, or is it just vibes?
It's mostly vibes, but I'm sure we could extract some nice guideline from all the examples we have in mathlib

pullRequest.title: feat(Algebra/Ring): generalise and extend material about sums of squares and semireal rings
